item.title: Link Collection - Calender Week 30
item.description: Some interessting links found in CW 30: Articles & Reports SANS Gold Paper - Windows 10 vs. Windows 11: What has changed ENISA Threat Landscape for Ransomware Attacks Blogs The 13 Deadly Sins of APT Incident Response â€” Part 1 Defense Evasion Series Part 1 - AMSI Bypass Blinding EDR On Windows How to Perform a Security Incident Response Tabletop Exercise Threat Hunting and Detection with Web Proxy Logs Old cat, new tricks, bad habits From RpcView to PetitPotam Wireshark plugin to work with Event Tracing for Windows Backdoor Office 365 and Active Directory - Golden SAML Living Off Windows Defender | LockBit Ransomware Sideloads Cobalt Strike Through Microsoft Security Tool How Threat Actors Are Adapting to a Post-Macro World dotnetfile Open Source Python Library: Parsing .

item.title: Memory Forensics of a Virtualbox VM
item.description: I use VirtualBox to triage and analyze malware. In contrast to VMWares .vmem file, VirtualBox does not use a separate file to store the current memory. Even if you take a snapshot or pause the VM, the current memory is not saved separately but stores the complete state of the VM in a .sav file. Luckily, Philippe Teuwen describes another way to dump the RAM of a (running) VirtualBox VM by using the VirtualBox debugvm capabilities.
